children.html:
Hello {first_name, "there"},

Friday! The weekend beckons, and now my youngest daughter is back at school, it actually feels like a different few days again. And I'll be glad to see the back of this week.

It has not been a happy time in the journalism world. Layoffs aplenty, and I suspect there will be many more to come. And at the other end of the scale, the tech elite are proving that they don't understand the concept of a free press. It's quite striking how people who have used the language of connecting people and making a better world to get very, very rich use very different language on their own.‌‌‌‌ And as long as that kind of hypocrisy is doing the rounds, there will be a need for good journalism.

There have been times during lockdown, when my income was looking shaky, and the industry started its quiet implosion, that I wondered if I wanted to stay in journalism. But reading stories like the Lean Back Read below makes me realise that what we do is important - and we need to get better at it.

A few more links than normal today, just to keep you entertained over the weekend. I hope you'll forgive me the indulgence.

children.text: Nobody is owed your attention

A couple of months ago I vaguely disagreed on Facebook with an acquaintance who is fairly big name author these days. He was opining on an area that wasn't his area of expertise — nor mine — but was my wife's. And I passed on her correction.  Much to my surprise, despite having happy memories of co-authoring something with him nearly 20 years ago, he unleashed both barrels and me, and a couple of his fans piled in, too.
It was the work of a moment to block him and them. He's clearly not my friend, and he is
not
owed my attention.
While tracking something else entirely, I discovered that the 'gentleman' in question has a reputation for being completely unable to handle
any

criticism at all. And yet he spends significant amounts of time assiduously farming attention on social media. I cannot begin to imagine the mental damage that those two behaviours in conjunction must be doing to his psyche.

For years, I've pointed out that journalists need to have a thick skin if they participate on social media. If you work in a profession which is rooted in challenging others, you must be open to some challenge yourself. Indeed, back in the mid-2000s, I spent significant amounts of time persuading colleagues that it was worth engaging with criticisms of their work, because often those criticisms were valid, and we could learn from them.
However, there is clearly a line where valid criticism crosses the line into abuse:

metadata.description: Helen Dalby, editor-in-chief of Reach’s titles in the North East, on how digital abuse towards journalists has got worse during lockdown — and what her newsrooms are doing about it: A…
metadata.author: Behind Local News

children.text: We're living through an age where politicians are raising the temperature of the rhetoric against journalists, and their followers are obediently aping that tone of voice. And there's a fine line to be walked between protecting ourselves and ceding the spaces of public discourse to the polarized factions.

Part of the solution is being more free with the block button. As I said, nobody is owed your attention, and people unable to act in a civilised way do not deserve even an iota of your time. But that approach is, at the very most, a plaster on an open wound of festering toxic discourse.
We clearly need to find a new way forwards - and this looks like a good start.

metadata.title: Conduct on social media may look different for journalists in the future. Let’s start figuring it out now. - Poynter
metadata.description: From person-to-person coaching and intensive hands-on seminars to interactive online courses and media reporting, Poynter helps journalists sharpen skills and elevate storytelling throughout their careers.
metadata.author: Barbara Allen

children.text: Advocate Media's solution to reader fatigue
Some useful strategies for addressing reader burnout here. The actual article below is a bit "meh", to be honest - but the links within it are well worth clicking through.
How climate change misinformation spreads
This is a useful, in-depth read on the organised elements behind some climate change "fake news" that spreads. We need more of this sort of granular analysis of types of misinformation.

metadata.title: Guest post: How climate change misinformation spreads online
metadata.description: The rapid rise of social media over the past two decades has brought with it a surge in misinformation. Online debates on topics such as vaccinations, presidential elections (pdf) and the coronavirus pandemic are often as vociferous as they are laced with misleading information.
metadata.author: Daisy Dunne

children.text: From TV presenter to universal credit

It's been a depressing week for layoffs in the journalism industry. But this piece, which I've had lurking in a tab for a few weeks, is a salutary reminder that the abrupt cessation of much of normal life meant that many journalists working as freelancers, but employed through their own companies, fell through the cracks of all the UK government support schemes months ago.

metadata.title: ‘I went from presenting the Six Nations for the BBC to having to claim Universal Credit’
metadata.description: Two million freelancers are missing out on emergency Covid-19 support, forcing an inquiry into what can be done to help them
metadata.author: Marianna Hunt

children.text: I'm so glad I never got around to setting myself up like that.
Free speech-centric platform Parler starts banning people
Mmmm. I love the smell of hypocrisy in the morning.
Turns out that if you want a particular type of community, you need to practice community management…

children.text: Indie Media: Read a Girl
A newsletter to help you
find more female authors
to add to your reading list.
The Lean Back Read: Tech 🤦🏼‍
Long term readers will know how interesting I find Taylor Lorenz's journalism. She's doing great work on the intersection of tech and culture, rather than tech and business - or even just pure tech.
However, she's attracted the attention of some of the Silicon Valley VC bros, and the results are far from edifying…
The old hippy tech utopianism is a crumbling façade at the best of times. This sort of behavior collapses it completely.

Talking of which, enjoy your few days off - if you get them - folks. And thanks for reading.
